Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Evolution of Plant Phenotypes, from Genomes to Traits to be held in Barcelona, Spain on March 17-18, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support attendance by U.S. scientists at the Conference on Evolution of Plant Phenotypes, from Genomes to Traits to be held in Barcelona, Spain on March 17-18, 2015. The meeting will include presentations by junior and senior investigators in a format that will promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings. Presentations will address a range of topics related to plant evolution, with the overarching aim of providing insights with potential applications to sustainable agriculture and food security.

The scientific goal of the meeting will be to connect genotype to phenotype by emphasizing two specific areas in plant evolution: effects of multiple rounds of whole genome doubling and contributions to genome evolution of proliferation and deletion of transposable elements. In these contexts, focus will be on domestication, breeding and local adaptation of crop genomes. To broadly share the outcomes of the meeting, presentations will be available from the conference website, and a meeting report will be published in a widely disseminated journal.

Funded by the Plant Genome Research Program in the Directorate of Biological Sciences, Division of Integrative Organismal Systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds were received to help defray approximately 10% of the cost of an international conference in Barcelona, specifically to provide partial reimbursement for the travel costs of the US invited speakers.  With the objective of reviewing the most recent advances in plant genomics, breeding, and molecular biology, and at the interface of these three fields, a group of scientists met in Barcelona in March 2015. The meeting was divided into three scientific sessions. The first concentrated on the mechanisms that generate genomic diversity in plants, while the second and third sessions were devoted to plant phenotypes in wild and domesticated species, and to plant improvement processes, respectively.   The objective of the conference was to seek synergy and to promote international, interdisciplinary thinking of relevance to crop adaptation and improvement, and their molecular genetic and genomic underpinnings. The conference was well-attended, many new contacts were established among the conference participants, and a report describing the conference proceedings is in press for publication in an international scientific journal with wide distribution. In total, the presentations at the conference revealed the extraordinary advances in our understanding of plant genome structure, genetic diversity, plant traits, and their possible interconnections and relevance to agriculturally important traits.
